results.title: Another day, another dollar: three short films about the history of work
results.brief_description:
“Projected memories: work in old films”: In 1947, a projectionist took a collection of instructional 16mm films about work to the bush. This short film includes excerpts from that collection covering early footage (1900s-1930s) of families on the land; factory workers; steel workers; coal miners; working women; the rise of trade-unions and the 8-hour day; peace campaign of 1938; the invention of the teleprinter; the arrival of the corner grocer shop and much more.
“Never done: women, work and history”: Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.
“Close to slavery: black work in white history”: It was government policy for Aboriginal Australians to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work whereas traditional Aborigines did not recognise the western idea of work and preferred to follow their own cultural identity. Then came the mission stations, removal of Aboriginal children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when black Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

results.title: Another day of healing
results.creator_credit: Leon Bram, Associated World, Film Partnership (Vic.) and Graham Bye
results.brief_description: In an attempt to cater for the medical needs of over 200,000 people annually, the Austin Hospital works twenty-four hours a day. The film shows the activities of all the departments of the Hospital and briefly tells some of its history. Written by John Hindle.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Leon Bram, Associated World, Film Partnership (Vic.) and Graham Bye

results.title: Another case of poisoning
results.creator_credit: Richard Massingham, Great Britain. Ministry of Health and John Waterhouse
results.brief_description: A film for food handlers of all kinds. A warning against the risks of food infection through neglect of the simple rules of hygiene. A food handler, suffering from poisoning is questioned by a doctor. The man recapitulates the events which led up to his illness. The film points out, by looking at the various locations he visited where food was handled, how he may have been infected due to dirty utensils, and unhealthy habits on the parts of cooks and food servers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Massingham, Great Britain. Ministry of Health and John Waterhouse

results.title: Another beginning
results.creator_credit: Brian Adams and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: Captures the Ballet Russe from its beginnings in Monte Carlo through its tour of Great Britain (1933) and later of Australia in 1936. The commentator, Wilfrid Thomas, discusses the impact of the Australian tour for the development of dance in Australia. Included are scenes from rehearsals of the Australian Ballet Company.

results.title: Anoop and the elephant
results.creator_credit: Hugh Stewart, Anvil Films, Children's Film Foundation and David Eady
results.brief_description: Engaging and highly entertaining children’s adventure story set in the world of the circus. Anoop, an Indian boy, and his friends attempt to rescue a performing elephant (Riley) from a life in the circus. Cast includes Jimmy Edwards.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hugh Stewart, Anvil Films, Children’s Film Foundation and David Eady

results.title: Annie's Coming Out (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Don Murray, Film Australia and Gil Brealey
results.brief_description: A warm, moving film experience and a triumph of the human spirit. “Annie’s Coming Out” is based on the true story of Annie McDonald. Jessica Hathaway (Angela Punch McGregor) works at a hospital for handicapped children, and among her charges is Annie, a victim of cerebral palsy. Discovering Annie’s considerable intelligence, Jessica endeavours to prove this and must take her case to court in a battle against the establishment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Murray, Film Australia and Gil Brealey

results.title: Annelids (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce J. Russell, Modern Learning Aids and Biomedia Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
A small anaesthetised earthworm is shown dissected, featuring the pumping heart. Shows peristaltic contractions which mix the food and send it along the intestinal tract. Undigested “castings” are expelled and their importance in soil ecology is discussed.

results.title: Annelid worms
results.brief_description: The following are studied: land earthworms, freshwater and saltwater aquatic worms; medicinal and pond leeches; numerous marine polchaet worms; and the most primitive type of annelid larva is illustrated by a study of the trochophore larva. No other credits available.
